Shoes Training Nutrition Run to Lose Subscribe Runners’ Stories Runners' Stories Did Running Save My Life? When I was 25, I ran away from a small town in Ohio. At age 46, I ran back to see how it—and I—had changed. By Mark Remy Thursday, June 1, 2017, 8:37 am Jordi Lafebre Certain creatures—salmon, puffins, sea turtles—travel great distances to return to their place of birth, usually to reproduce. It’s a process called “natal homing,” and scientists aren’t sure exactly how it works. They suspect things like geomagnetic imprinting play a role. When I returned to my own birthplace, a journey of about 2,400 miles, I used American Airlines. Advertisement Advertisement Newsletters Delivered to your inbox warmup Quote of the Day, motivation, and inspiration — every morning rundown Advice on training, nutrition, shoes, and more — every evening Keep this field blank Enter your email address You may unsubscribe at any time. Privacy Policy | About Us I decided to go back, some 20 years after I’d left, for a few reasons: The place still exerted a pull on me, for reasons I didn’t understand. (Geomagnetic imprinting? Could be.) I was curious to overlay what was there today on the place I remember from my youth. Also I couldn’t shake the feeling that I had unfinished business there, emotionally. More than anything, I went back as a sort of pilgrimage. Circleville, Ohio, a town of about 13,000 some 30 miles south of Columbus, wasn’t just where I was born—it’s where I became a runner. I’d come to realize just how crucial that development was for me, both personally and professionally. As in, If I hadn’t become a runner, my life today would look very, very different. And probably not in a good way. I wanted to go back and drive the roads I’d traced, over and over and over, first as a cyclist and then as a runner. I wanted to track down old friends, including a guy named Denny—the man who, pretty much single-handedly, turned me into a runner. I also wanted to do some thinking. Not just about my past and my present and how one informed the other—still informs it, in fact—but about the nature of growth, about the power of running to strengthen us in ways that go way beyond physical, about fate. I also wanted to see whether Lindsey’s Bakery was still there, and if so whether they still made those smiley-face cookies. (It is, and they do.) Jordi Lafebre In my fantasy, the stepfather—I still don’t like to use his name—is buckled into the back seat of a sedan as it slowly fills with tear gas. He’s scared. He grows agitated, then frantic, screaming. He pounds on the windows. Through a speaker I’ve placed in the car, I explain things slowly, as I watch him writhe: “We don’t need to roll the windows down to get fresh air,” I say. “Someday I’ll show you how this car’s air-circulation system works.” Because that’s what he told me when I was 10, after he lit a cigarette and I asked him to crack a window. Cigarette smoke wasn’t the only thing awful about the stepfather. But it was the most noxious, literally, and I’ve associated that smell with him ever since. During his reign, cigarettes were omnipresent. In the living room. At the dinner table. The laundry room. And, of course, in the car. Today I believe that I became a cyclist, and then a runner, at least in part as a repudiation of this—as a way to do something, anything, in response. It was my way of giving this guy the finger without actually giving him the finger. What’s the diametric opposite of filling your lungs with carcinogenic smoke? Filling them with fresh air, out on an open road. Over and over and over, for miles at a time. RELATED: Avoid Pollutants for Breathing No Matter Where You Live If I run fast enough, far enough, will it rid my hair and clothing of that stale nicotine stench? Not quite. But it’s nice to imagine. Will I escape for real someday? Bust out and just keep running? You bet your ass I will. And every mile I log, every step I take, gets me a little bit stronger and a little bit closer. I knew that my love of cycling and running was a positive thing, even back then, and I knew they were making me healthier and stronger. I just didn’t grasp the full extent of it. Not then. Now I do. Now, too, I feel a strange blend of gratitude and horror. I’m grateful for running and everything it’s done for me. Horrified when I pause to imagine how easily I could have missed out on all of it. Jordi Lafebre The Pickaway County YMCA is a blocky flat-topped building on the east side of town, just north of Circleville High. My life began at Berger Hospital, a mile west, in 1970. But my life as a runner began here, at the Y, circa 1994. It was winter break and I was home from school. I’d been running a little, as off-season cross-training for cycling, so I bought a temporary pass to the Y, which had a 115-meter indoor track. That’s where I met Denny. Denny was older, with a daughter my age, and had a habit of befriending and mentoring young runners. He was a blue-collar guy, compact and strong, soft-spoken but funny. His calves seemed carved from stone. He always had a deep tan, even in winter, and carefully combed hair. Really, you should have seen his hair. He was quiet, but pulled no punches. One of the first things he did was make me buy new shoes. (When we met, I ran in tennis shoes. And not in the generic, Midwest sense that all athletic shoes are “tennis shoes.” I mean they were tennis shoes.) Under his watch, I learned about nutrition, hydration, racing, recovery, etiquette. All of it. Denny was Runner’s World personified. On Denny’s advice I registered for a Valentine’s Day run, a 15-miler, and ran well enough to snag an age-group award. A coffee mug. I still keep it on a shelf in my office. That race was my final exam and graduation ceremony all rolled into one. A few months later I would run my first marathon. RELATED: First Marathon Advice and Tips I thought a lot about Denny as I planned my visit, trying without luck to track him down. As far as Google was concerned, he didn’t exist. I asked friends who still had ties to the area. Nothing. So I know it’s a long shot—it’s been 20 years, after all—but once I get to town I drive to the YMCA and ask the woman behind the counter: “This name ring a bell? Tan guy? Runner? Used to come here all the time?” Nope, sorry. I give up. Until it occurs to me (duh) to check a phone book. I reach him, finally, and we schedule a meeting. I’ll swing by his house in a couple of days. Till then, I have some exploring to do, and some running, and one other reunion with an old friend. Jordi Lafebre When he was 29, my father was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. Thirteen days later he was gone. I was 6. I’ve spent the better part of my life since then trying to strike a balance between “moving past” this trauma and obsessing over it—acknowledging that it’s surely affected my development, my personality, my relationships, and so on, without ceding control over those things or wallowing in self-pity or ever using it as an excuse. It was hard, of course, losing my dad at such a young age. Hard, too, having a toddler sister who couldn’t begin to understand what was happening and a mother who understood all too well. My mom would remarry a few years later, and we’d all move to a new house in a new school district. With the stepfather and his cartons of Kents. He would be in the picture until, roughly, my sophomore year of high school—shortly after I became an athlete. I have few memories of my father, and what memories I do have are hazy. But I’ve always had an idea of the kind of man he was, and the kind of man he’d want me to be. As I wrote a few years back, in a Father’s Day column: I’d be lying if I said that I began running because of my dad, or that I dedicate every single run to his memory, or anything that dramatic. Still. He sometimes drifts into my thoughts while I’m running, and especially while I’m racing. Sometimes, if I’m patient enough, a tiny bit of it does make sense. Sometimes, I realize—14 years after the fact—that when I ran my fastest-ever marathon, it was in Ohio, about a half hour’s drive north of the cemetery where my father is buried. Then I realize that I was 29 years old at the time, and that my mother was there to see me finish. Is it possible that, all this time, I’ve been running not from something or toward something, but for something? For someone? A man I never really knew? I’ll never know for sure. What I do know is that during my recent visit the first stop I made, even before I checked into my hotel, was the cemetery where my father is buried. It’s a big cemetery. I hadn’t been there in years. But my car steered itself over the winding gravel lanes to exactly the right spot. Welcome home. Circleville still doesn’t have a running store. But hey—now there’s a gun shop on Main Street. What else is new? Not a lot. I’m not sure what I expected, but 20 years later the town looks more or less the same. I almost feel let down. Apart from the gun shop—a T-shirt in the window suggests that Democrats can shove gun control up their [picture of donkey]—there’s a hulking Walmart Supercenter just south of town, with the usual assortment of shops and restaurants that surround big-box stores like remoras clinging to a whale. So you’ve got your Buffalo Wild Wings, your GameStop, your Great Clips. There’s a combination Long John Silver’s/KFC restaurant. Next door to all this is the abandoned RCA factory. It used to produce glass TV picture tubes 24 hours a day, seven days a week. I worked there for a couple of summers during college. One of those summers I did a bike race, a time trial, in a nearby town the morning of a 4:00-to-midnight shift. Only race I ever won. The factory closed in 2004. Last I heard, the Ohio EPA had a plan for “removal of lead and other industrial contaminants” on the site. I see a few dollar stores. Those are new. A lot of confederate flags, too. I see them streaming behind pickups, in front of homes. Those are new, too. Or did I just not notice them before? I realize how many of these places—streets, blocks, intersections—are backdrops in my dreams. That’s a little surreal. I head out of town, almost on autopilot. Here’s my high school, and the junior high, where I made a pathetic attempt to join the track team and positively sucked in the hundred-yard dash. I stop to have a look inside. It’s summer, so I have the halls to myself. Same polished floors, same seafoam-green tile in the men’s room, same vaguely antiseptic smell. Same classrooms, including the one where our history teacher, also a preacher, told us that carbon dating was a lie. I learn from a cheerful woman in the office that the school no longer offers journalism. The student newspaper is gone, too, she says. That stings. I drive on, to the old neighborhood, a small subdivision a few miles east of town. It’s remarkably unchanged. My childhood home looks tired, though—a painted aluminum shutter hangs loose and a shabby fence surrounds the backyard. Then I hear gunshots. I’d forgotten there’s a gun range across the road. Later, when I check its website, I read a headline on the homepage: “When the Killer’s Gun Jams…Can You Recognize an Opportunity for Action?” Onward. Here’s the house of a high school classmate who killed himself after graduation. Here’s Circleville Bible College, except now it’s called Ohio Christian University, which sounds like a promotion to me. Oh, yeah. Here’s where the stepfather’s parents lived. I hated this house. The stepfather’s father was a one-armed man who took great pride in the plants and flowers he grew and was a vocal racist. I still remember him passing through a room and glimpsing The Cosby Show on TV. “I don’t want to see those n------s,” he said. These places are all dots on a mental map, connected the way detectives link mugshots on a big bulletin board. I think of this map today and imagine all those years of biking and running over it, every direction, in lines, loops, and squiggles, trying to scribble over something that couldn’t be erased. Jordi Lafebre I hadn’t seen Kevin since college. In high school we’d been close friends—I only had a handful—and after that we both went to Ohio University, in Athens. Then things went bad. In my last vivid memory of Kevin (a pseudonym), it’s freshman year and I’m in my dorm room, trying to sleep. It’s late. He and my roommate (another Circleville kid) are sitting near my bed. They’ve been drinking and are taunting me. Not in a friendly, joshing sort of way. It’s hostile. Specifically it’s about my cycling. They’re conversing loudly about it, amusing themselves. “Gotta get up early to ride your bike,” one of them says. “Riding around and around and around in circles,” says the other. “And getting nowhere.” “Ending up right where you began.” I imagine this attitude is fairly typical among the people I grew up with. But hearing it from these two hurts. A few years ago, I found Kevin on Facebook and we did a little catching up. He was still in Circleville, married, with a kid. He ended our chat with this: “Oh yeah, sorry for being such a d—-at OU. It still bothers me. If you ever come back this way, get in touch.” So I did. We meet at a sports bar on Main Street. I arrive early and order a beer. Soon after, Kevin enters and walks right by me until I call out. “Dude!” He’s a bit heavier now. His eyes look tired. There’s dirt under his nails. We sit and drink. It’s awkward, but less so as the beer does its thing. We discuss life since school, his and mine. Kevin mentions that he tried running a while back. “I went out and bought these shoes,” he says, showing me the Brooks he’s worn to the bar. “Ran around Hargus Lake. Hurt my bones. Oh my God, I was aching.” He hasn’t run since. Does he see anyone else from our class? A few guys, he says, rattling off some names. He mentions one in particular. “He went around with an engagement ring in his pocket,” Kevin says. “Seriously. He married some old bar hag.” He steps outside for a smoke. Kevin left college with a business degree, but a low GPA and a bad job market made finding work tough. So he looked to the factories where he’d worked summers during school. He landed a job, was laid off, found another. Somewhere along the line, he decided he would learn to fly. So he did. “Still carry my license,” he tells me. He pulls out his wallet, digs around, and slaps a pilot’s license on the bar. He hasn’t flown in years. “Can’t afford it.” Flying was supposed to be Kevin’s ticket out. At one point he quit his job and went to Florida, seeking work in aviation. Then his wife got pregnant. So back he went to Ohio, this time for good. “Now I’m stuck here,” he says. There’s no bitterness or resentment in his voice. Just acceptance. Well, that’s life. Another round? Sure. Cheers. We finish our beers, wrap things up, share a quick hug. He walks out the back door to his car. I walk out the front door to mine. It doesn’t occur to me at the time, but this is probably the last time we’ll ever see each other. Life is a series of small choices that can have profound effects. It’s so random. And so scary. This, I think, is another reason I run. Running helps me cope with this knowledge, this randomness and scariness. When I run, whether it’s for 20 minutes or two hours, life isn’t random or scary anymore. The big picture shrinks to a more manageable size. Running, I come to realize, is the stitching that’s held my life together. Not just day to day but year to year, life stage to life stage. Jordi Lafebre Running followed me from Ohio to Pennsylvania, where I knew exactly zero people and began my professional life. Then to New York, where a therapist asked me, in our first session, if I keep photos of my father near me and I pulled out my wallet to show him a black-and-white senior year portrait and then started crying. Then back to Pennsylvania, where I got married and started a family, then to Oregon. In the background, though, always, there is Circleville. Where my own small choices (and some dumb luck) would put me on a path leading out. Where biking and running would help to shape my identity, help me cope, help me escape. How? By training me to step out of my comfort zone. To believe that I could do something, and then do it (or at least try). To face a fork in the road and choose the scarier route over the safer one. RELATED: 7 Ways That Running Makes You a Better Person Can I ride my bike 100 miles in five hours? Yeah, I can do that. Train through searing Ohio summers and deep-freeze Ohio winters, with plastic bags over my socks to prevent frostbite? Hey, I can do that, too. Run a marathon? Yep. Pack a U-Haul and leave everything and everyone I know for someplace new? Let’s do it. All those years on my bike and in my running shoes, I was like a guy tunneling out of prison with a spoon. The work was quiet and painfully incremental. But each day got me a little bit closer to freedom. Until one day, I broke through. Jordi Lafebre When I reach out to shake Denny’s hand, he pulls me in. We haven’t seen each other in at least 20 years. Now we’re hugging in his living room, in a modest ranch house just outside town. “It’s good to see you again,” he says. His eyes still crinkle when he smiles. I tell him it’s good to see him, too, and that he looks great. Which he does. “I’ve gone white,” he says. “And fat.” In fact, Denny’s hair has gone gray—not sure I’d call it white—and he does have a small belly. But little else has changed. He’s got the same twinkle in his eye, he’s just as quick to grin. You still get the vague sense that he’s up to something. We head into his carpeted living room, past a treadmill. “It doesn’t get much use anymore,” Denny tells me. He brings two cups of coffee and two packets of nondairy creamer. We sit and talk. At age 76, Denny has been retired for a few years. He doesn’t run much these days, he says, though I don’t entirely buy that. Partly because I can’t imagine him not running and partly because he’s always been modest to a fault. (At one point he tries telling me he was never really a runner, just “a guy who liked to run.” When I first met him, Denny ran nearly every day. His philosophy on rest days was “rest is what sleep is for.”) His memory is still sharp. “I remember you didn’t want to run,” he says, recalling the day we met. “Didn’t see any sense in it.” Sounds about right to me. I recall biking with a friend, back in the day, and shouting as we passed a runner, “You’re going to ruin your knees!” Yeah. I was one of those guys. Sorry. Denny remembers ordering me into proper running shoes. He remembers recommending Sauconys. He remembers that the Sauconys I bought were purple. He remembers how hard it was to be a runner in Circleville 20 years ago. “You’d get spit on, rocks thrown at you,” he says. “Not many people around here ran.” Today, he tells me, there are runners “everywhere” in Circleville. I wouldn’t go that far—during my three days there I saw just a handful. But everything is relative. After a long goodbye and another hug, I drive off. Denny calls me 20 minutes later. “I never asked how your running was going,” he says, sounding regretful. I tell him, in broad strokes—lots of races, including 26 marathons. Some Bostons. Writing for Runner’s World. And so on. “Well, I always told you you were a runner,” he says. “You didn’t believe me.” At a fundamental level, running is about travel. And travel is about going someplace else, someplace new. You run, you move. You get stronger and more confident. Run long enough, and you begin to equate movement with energy and growth and discovery. Sitting still? That equals sloth, atrophy, confinement. Ultimately, death. Growing up, my hometown was all about sitting still. Even before I knew what the word provincial meant, I knew it was a provincial place. It still is, at least among older residents. Like those who reacted to the news that we’d gotten our infant daughter a passport not with, “How exciting! Where are you going?” but with a puzzled, “What does she need that for?” Running helped me navigate that world. And then catapulted me out of it. Eventually, through running, I’d see Iowa, North Carolina, South Carolina, California, Alaska, Oregon, Chicago, Virginia, Colorado, Boston, Vermont, Florida, Hawaii. Italy. And now, back to Circleville. Jordi Lafebre After spending a few days here, dredging and reconnecting, I’m still no closer to knowing whether the town has changed much, or whether I have. Probably both. The day before I leave, I meet a Facebook friend for a run at Hargus Lake—the same place where Kevin tried to run and “hurt his bones.” Same place I took hikes with fellow Boy Scouts as we prepared for a trip out West, our backpacks weighed down with gallon jugs of water. My first experience with endurance training. TRAIN WITH RW: Plans for every distance (and every runner) in 3 easy ways! I’m reminded here that running isn’t only about the places it takes you, but the people you meet along the way. Two others have joined us for our run—a woman who recently moved to Circleville from Seattle and a kid who just graduated from high school in a town 45 minutes away—a place even smaller than Circleville. Ben (let’s call him) is wearing a headband. Ben is quiet. I like Ben already. We run around the lake, chatting and leaping over streams. We walk some of the hills. Afterward we stand in the parking lot where we’d met, talking. It’s like a prayer circle, except we aren’t praying. (Or are we?) We talk about running and how it brings people together. Also about how it seems to adapt to your emotional needs, helping you cope with everything. I don’t get into my own backstory, but my friend describes how running helped her through a divorce. Ben mentions depression and anxiety and describes how it affects his running, and vice versa. Ben is tall and thin and slightly awkward—he reminds me of myself at his age. As we head to our cars, I tell him that I’m glad he mentioned his depression. Too often, people are afraid to talk about that stuff, which only makes things worse. I tell Ben that I’ve dealt with those same issues for most of my adult life. That meds and therapy have helped beyond measure. I tell him not to be shy about asking for help. Definitely keep running, I tell him. It won’t cure your depression and anxiety. But it can be an enormous help as you cope with those things. He nods. As we part ways, I tell him that he’ll be okay. Things will be okay, really. And I mean it. Tags: Runners' StoriesRW June 2017Featured ContentMotivation Comments Show comments Privacy Policy  |  About Us Copyright © 2017 Rodale Inc. Informa Resource Center Article Archives Ashwagandha Advantage Blogs Buyer’s Guide Classic Digital Magazines Editor's Choice Awards Flaxseed Research Center Galleries Infographics Ingredient Buying Center Jobs Podcasts Reports Webinars Whitepapers Video Digital Summits Documentaries INSIDER TV Categories Animal Nutrition Contract Manufacturing Digestive Health Essential Fatty Acids (EFAs) Eye Health Joint Health Minerals Plant-Based Ingredients Snack Foods Sports Nutrition Tableting Weight Management Women's Health More Topics Events Ingredient Marketplace SupplySide West Vitafoods Asia Vitafoods Europe Buyer's Guide Ingredients Health Conditions Contract Manufacturing Packaging CPG Awards FTC Mailing Additional Refunds to Consumers who Purchased Green Coffee Bean Extract Blog May 31, 2017 The FTC on Tuesday divulged it is refunding consumers who bought green coffee bean extract supplements from retailers like Walmart, reflecting the second mailing of refunds related to the same lawsuit against Pure Health LLC, Genesis Today Inc., and their principal, Lindsey Duncan. The agency is mailing nearly 39,000 refund checks totaling US$1.9 million to consumers who purchased the products from retailers, according to an FTC news release. In June 2016, the agency used the defendants’ sales records to mail refunds to nearly 200,000 people who purchased the products online, according to the news release. Under a claims process FTC announced when the first checks were mailed, individuals who submitted valid claims before the deadline are receiving full refunds, averaging $49.66 each, the agency said. The previous refunds from the online purchases averaged $47.93 each. In a complaint filed in January 2015, FTC alleged the defendants deceptively claimed the supplement would cause individuals to lose 17 pounds and 16 percent of their body fat in 12 weeks without diet or exercise, and that the claim was supported by a clinical study. Under a settlement with the agency, the defendants are prohibited from making deceptive weight loss claims about any food or dietary supplement, and they were required to set aside money for the refund program. In a similar lawsuit last year, a judge ordered the co-founder of a green coffee extract business to surrender $29.1 million after finding the businessman’s companies made unsupported weight loss claims, operated fake news websites, and failed to reveal women touting the product were paid for their testimonials. In support of weight loss claims that drew FTC’s attention, the defendant predominantly relied on a small study that was highlighted in a 2012 episode of The Dr. Oz Show. But the government said participants lost most of their weight while they were not taking any green coffee antioxidant capsules. Fox News Fox Business Fox News Go Fox News Radio Fox Nation Fox News Insider   Welcome, {username} Profile | Login Fox News U.S. Expand/Collapse Search Home Video Politics U.S. Opinion Business Entertainment Tech Science Health Travel Lifestyle World On Air TERROR Ohio State attacker faulted 'moderate' Muslims in note to family Published June 02, 2017 Associated Press Facebook Twitter Email Print FILE - In this Nov. 28, 2016, file photo, crime scene investigators collect evidence from the pavement as police respond to an attack on the Ohio State University campus in Columbus, Ohio.  (AP) COLUMBUS, Ohio –  A man responsible for a car-and-knife attack at Ohio State University last year left behind a torn-up note in which he urged his family to stop being "moderate" Muslims and said he was upset by fellow Muslims being oppressed in Myanmar, The Associated Press has learned. Abdul Razak Ali Artan also told his parents in the note, reassembled by investigators, that he "will intercede for you in the day of Judgment," according to the investigative case file of the attack obtained through an open records request. "My family stop being moderate muslims," says the handwritten note transcribed by investigators and found by Artan's bed in his family's apartment. Artan also wrote: "In the end, I would like to say that I pledge my allegiance to 'dawla,'" an Arabic word that means state or country and a likely reference to the Islamic State group. "May Allah bless them." He concludes by saying he's leaving his property to his beloved "but yet 'moderate mother.'" Artan's family was baffled by that note, which caused them a great deal of anguish, said Bob Fitrakis, a Columbus attorney representing the family. To this day, the family has no idea why Artan took those actions, he said Thursday. "The family is mystified by what happened. They're absolutely clueless," Fitrakis said. The 18-year-old Artan was shot and killed by an Ohio State officer moments after driving into a crowd on Nov. 28 and then attacking people with a knife, leaving thirteen injured. In a series of Facebook rants previously reported, Artan nursed grievances against the U.S. "If you want us Muslims to stop carrying lone wolf attacks, then make peace" with the Islamic State group, he warned in those posts in which he also railed against U.S. intervention in Muslim lands. Artan posted those comments at 9:49 a.m. on Nov. 28, three minutes before the attack began, according to an unclassified FBI report showing the time line of the attack that was released through the open records request. One of his brothers saw those comments and tried too late to contact him, thinking maybe it was a joke or his account had been hacked, Fitrakis said. The records provided new details about Artan, including a visit he made to Washington, D.C., a few days before the attack where he also made unidentified purchases at a Walmart. The family didn't realize he'd traveled there, has no idea why he went, and urges anyone with information about that trip to contact authorities, Fitrakis said. The day before the attack, Artan left his job at a nearby Home Depot, saying he was tired, a co-worker told investigators. This was unusual, "as he never left early from work," the co-worker said. Artan had told the co-worker several times that fall he was disgruntled with school and wanted to drop out, according to the records. The morning of the attack, Artan bought a set of knives, a tomato and a cucumber at 7:20 a.m. at a Walmart on the west side of Columbus, with his movements captured by video and photos and released in response to the AP's records' request. The "suspect was pleasant and very polite during the checkout process," the Walmart cashier told investigators. At 7:50 a.m., Artan dropped his sister at a high school near their home on the city's west side. He paid a brother $40 he owed him around 9:30 a.m., when the brother last saw him, according to FBI records. After arriving on campus, Artan drove his brother's Honda Civic over a curb and into a crowd of people and crashed it into a planter. Artan then got out and started slashing at people with an eight-inch knife, records show. In a coincidence, a nearby building had been evacuated because of a reported gas leak. "I'm going to . . . kill you," Artan told one female student, using an expletive, the records show. Somali-born Artan came to the U.S. in 2014 as the child of a refugee. He had been living in Pakistan from 2007 to 2014. Authorities believe Artan's attack was partly inspired by an American-born cleric killed in a U.S. drone strike in Yemen. Advertisement Trending in US Portland stabbings: Police search for man who allegedly swiped victim's belongings Unflappable Ananya Vinay wins National Spelling Bee Man who used emojis to advise killers to be sentenced Memorable words from the National Spelling Bee The Latest: ACLU against effort to allow Trump travel ban Site Index Sections Home Video Politics U.S. Opinion Entertainment Tech Science Health Travel Lifestyle World Sports Weather On Air Tools Live Video Newsletters Alerts Podcasts Radio Apps & Products About Careers College Students Fox Around the World Advertise With Us New Terms of Use (What's New) New Privacy Policy Ad Choices Help Email Newsroom Media Relations Closed Captioning Policy Follow Facebook Twitter Google+ Instagram RSS Newsletters Fox News Back to Top This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. 2017 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved. All market data delayed 20 minutes.
Toggle navigation Toggle navigation Home Samachar News Finance SPORTS Movies Bawarchi Astrology Videos Gold rates DUBAI GOLD RATES RUPEE Jobs Health Antzill Techtalk Web Sify Search Sify.com Finance Equity U.S. coal stocks fall; exit from climate deal may hurt, not help U.S. coal stocks fall; exit from climate deal may hurt, not help Source : By : Rodrigo Campos and Nichola Groom Last Updated: Fri, Jun 02, 2017 10:13 hrs NEW YORK/LOS ANGELES: U.S. coal company shares dipped alongside renewable energy stocks on Wednesday after reports that President Donald Trump plans to pull the United States from a global accord on fighting climate change. The market reaction reflects concerns, raised by some coal companies in recent months, that a U.S. exit from the Paris Climate Agreement could unleash a global backlash against coal interests outside the United States. Peabody Energy, the largest publicly traded U.S. coal company dropped 2.2 percent to $24.29 a share, while Arch Coal fell 0.4 percent to $70.77. A spokesman for Peabody said the company would support a decision by Trump to withdraw from the Paris deal because the "accord is flawed on a number of levels." Cloud Peak Energy Inc had also urged the Trump administration to stay in the Paris deal to prevent other nations from an aggressive turn against the global coal industry. Its shares were down 0.6 percent to $3.39. A spokesman for Cloud Peak declined to comment. A source briefed on the matter told Reuters that Trump is planning to follow through on his campaign pledge to pull the United States out of the Paris accord, a move designed to help boost domestic energy production and speed economic growth, after weeks of deliberations on the issue. Trump did not confirm the decision, but said he would make an announcement "over the coming days". CAMPAIGN PLEDGE A U.S. withdrawal would come over the objections of scores of big U.S. corporations - from Wal-Mart to Exxon Mobil - worried the move will complicate the business landscape instead of bolstering the economy. "For us, our position on the Paris agreement... we need a framework like that to address the risks of climate change," Exxon Mobil Chief Executive Officer Darren Woods told reporters on the sidelines of the company's annual general meeting on Wednesday. Exxon had made that case in a recent letter to the White House, he said. Exxon dipped 0.7 percent, ConocoPhillips declined 0.2 percent, and Chevron Corp fell 0.6 percent. Crude oil prices fell to a three-week low on news that recovering Libyan output boosted OPEC crude output in May. Solar energy shares also got hit on Wednesday, with First Solar Inc down 2.5 percent, and SunPower Corp each down 3.4 percent. "Regardless of what the President decides on the accord, we expect America’s solar industry to continue to thrive and create jobs, boost the economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions," the Solar Energy Industries Association said in a statement. Shares of Tesla Inc, which recently acquired SolarCity, were up 1.8 percent at $341.01. Tesla CEO Elon Musk said in a Twitter post on Wednesday that he had done "all I can" to convince Trump to stay in the Paris accord, and threatened to leave White House advisory councils if Trump announces a U.S. exit. Trump campaigned on a promise to unravel Obama-era climate regulations to help boost domestic oil, gas and coal production. Company executives, economists, and analysts have expressed skepticism, however, that his deregulatory agenda can alter existing trends away from coal. U.S. carbon emissions have declined to near 30-year lows, a trend driven by increased natural gas use replacing coal. The VanEck Vectors Coal exchange-traded fund (KOL.P) fell 1.2 percent to $12.71, not far from a five-month low hit earlier in May. The ETF is on track to fall 7.2 percent this month after rising in the first three months of the year as part of the so-called Trump trade. msn back to msn home news web search Sign in Change language and content: América Latina (español) Argentina (español) Australia (English) België (Nederlands) Belgique (français) Brasil (português) Canada (English) Canada (français) Chile (español) Colombia (español) Danmark (Dansk) Deutschland (Deutsch) España (español) France (français) India (English) Indonesia (Bahasa Indonesia) Ireland (English) Italia (italiano) Malaysia (English) México (español) Nederland (Nederlands) New Zealand (English) Norge (norsk, bokmål) Österreich (Deutsch) Perú (español) Philippines (English) Polska (polski) Portugal (Português) Schweiz (Deutsch) Singapore (English) South Africa (English) Suisse (français) Suomi (suomi) Sverige (svenska) Türkiye (Türkçe) United Arab Emirates (English) United Kingdom (English) United States (English) United States (español) Venezuela (español) Việt Nam (Tiếng Việt) Ελλάδα (ελληνικά) Россия (Pусский) ישראל (עברית)‏ الإمارات العربية المتحدة (العربية‏) المملكة العربية السعودية (العربية‏) مصر (العربية‏) ไทย (ไทย) 한국 (한국어) 中华人民共和国 (简体中文) 台灣 (繁體中文) 日本 (日本語) 香港特别行政區 (繁體中文) Feedback Headlines India Climate vs Trump Science & Tech Crime World Offbeat Photos Video Mission Admission 2017 Specials Local My Topics Home News Weather Entertainment Sports Money Lifestyle Health Food Travel Autos Video News Sections India World Science & Tech Photos My Topics Local Trump just passed on the best deal the planet has ever seen The Guardian David Suzuki 2 hours ago SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL Two dead in Indonesia blasts Analysis: Why Trump’s withdrawal from Paris pact doesn’t make sense © AP ‘By withdrawing from this historical agreement, Trump will make more enemies than friends.’ Since day one as a contender for the Oval Office, current US President Donald Trump has pushed a dominant narrative: he’s a businessman. He gets economics. He knows the art of the deal. This week, with his decision to withdraw the US from the Paris Agreement, the president has given the world strong reason to reject that narrative. His rationale — that it’s a choice of economy over environment, and a fossil fuel economy is the top priority — is outdated and false. States and nations around the world have harvested the fruits of clean energy, and are redefining their economies and energy sources accordingly. Yet, under false pretenses that “clean coal,” natural gas and other fossil fuel fixes are better than energy conservation and clean energy, the US forges its own, lonely path. The idea that clean, renewable energy will generate power for our planet for generations to come is not rhetoric. The extent of human-caused climate change — and the rapidly improving economics driving the proliferation of renewable energy sources — make it fact. If the US administration isn’t ready to move forward, hundreds of individual states and other countries will. California is already a world leader on climate policy. Texas is rapidly expanding its wind energy capacity. In Germany, clean energy has become a movement itself, focused on thousands of small-scale projects under the Energiewende program. In Scotland, wind generation has increased by 81% over the past year, and in March this year, it produced enough energy to satisfy 136 % of the country’s household energy needs. These are just a few examples. The US’s withdrawal doesn’t mean Americans and US investors will sit still, either. There is substantial economic opportunity in renewables. The US solar industry alone creates one in 50 new jobs. Worldwide, nearly 10 million people already work in renewable energy. Global clean technology exports doubled between 2008 and 2015, surpassing $1.15tn per year. Even America’s corporate giants — from Apple and Google to Walmart, and even oil giant Exxon Mobil — support the Paris Agreement. The economics are clear. So what about the political implications of the decision? By withdrawing from this historical agreement, Trump will make more enemies than friends. Polling results from Yale University’s Climate Change in the American Mind survey (conducted after the US election) show that 73% of Trump voters want the US to use more renewable energy. (His own supporters!) As recently as May 7, a small but increasingly vocal group of Republicans has embraced the reality of global warming, taking steps to press the issue in Congress. Elsewhere in the world, 195 countries and the European Union have signed the Paris Agreement, 147 of which have ratified it. Only Nicaragua and Syria have not signed on. When news of the potential withdrawal reached the United Nations, the organization’s Twitter page read: “Climate change is undeniable. Climate change is unstoppable. Climate solutions provide opportunities that are unmatchable.” A Globe and Mail report showed that even fossil fuel companies — the likes of Exxon Mobil, BP and Shell — think the US should stick with Paris. This withdrawal is an ugly decision, made by a country that ought to be leading the transition to a cleaner future — not only because of its stature as an international economic powerhouse, but also because of its less-than-desirable environmental track record. After China, the US is the world’s second-largest greenhouse gas polluter. In response, China has been become a leading producer of solar energy technology and is slowing its coal power construction. The US, meanwhile, hangs on to a coal industry that should have been dissolved decades ago. Just north of the border in Canada, where I live, the situation is delicate. We have been plagued by recent missteps such as approval of fossil-fuel-driven pipeline projects, but at least our governments claim a commitment to a sustainable, clean energy future. In my home province of British Columbia, recent election results may even reverse the approval of some of those infrastructure projects. But we’re far from safe ground. These types of actions by the US administration show that environmental rights — for Canada and all countries around the world — are vital, now more than ever. Yet, while 110 countries worldwide have environmental rights written into their constitutions, Canada does not. I tend to focus my advice on domestic matters like these. But today, I offer a word to the US president: A global shift to renewable energy is on. There’s no denying it or turning it around. It’s good for business. This is not fake news. It’s real life. And it’s happening with or without you. You claim you know a good deal when you see one. Well, you just passed on one of the best our planet has ever seen. GoSearch Replay: Latest Broadcast 5NEWS TV Schedule Search Contact Us Fort Smith/Fayetteville News | 5newsonline KFSM 5NEWS Menu News Sports Health Traffic On-Air Contests Events Weather Ft. Smith 67° Low 65° High 85° Fayetteville 60° Low 60° High 82° Bentonville 63° Low 61° High 81° See complete forecast Fort Smith Police Investigate Credit Card Phishing Scam Posted 10:22 pm, June 1, 2017, by Krystle Sherrell Share this: Facebook Twitter Google Pinterest LinkedIn Email Please enable Javascript to watch this video FORT SMITH (KFSM) -- The Fort Smith Police Department is working alongside local banks after more than a dozen people in the River Valley filed reports of fraudulent charges on their accounts within the last two weeks. One of those victims was business owner Redd Rahman. "I pulled up my account on my computer at home to pay some online bills and I checked my account before I started paying bills," Rahman said. "The very first thing I noticed was a debit from the day before that I never even made." Police said the people responsible for the phishing scam are from Miami and used a rental car to travel to the stores where transactions were made. "What we've seen is a group that made various transactions at our local Walmarts, Central Mall, convenience stores, liquor stores, and we've had over the last 15 days," Sgt. Daniel Grubbs, Fort Smith Police Department said. "We've had about 13 of those where the people's accounts that were compromised; they never lost possession of those cards." For victims like Rahman, that one swipe from scammers has led to a much bigger hassle. "That's extremely upsetting," Rahman said. "This was my business account. This account is associated with my business and my livelihood. It's associated with how I earn my money, where my money is and how I maintain my life and take care of my family." Police said they are unsure how the scammers obtained the account information. "We don't know how," Grubbs said. "We don't know if it's been through a transaction locally, a transaction through the internet or how this information was obtained. Phishing is one way that people's accounts are obtained. Rahman said he now knows it can happen to anyone. "I've heard about scams like this, but my mentality was always that I would be safe because they hack into the accounts of rich people, people with a lot of money," Rahmam said. "I don't have a lot of money and they hacked into my account. That opened my eyes. No one is safe." Rahman said his one piece of advice is to pay attention to your bank accounts. "Be extremely cautious," Rahman said. "Maybe I'll go back to putting my money in my mattress." The executive vice-president of Arvest said if you believe you may be a victim of the phishing scam, contact your bank immediately. "Those folks at your financial institution, they're gonna know exactly how to walk you through the steps you're going to need to get your money back," Gaye Wilcox said. Another way to protect yourself is by making sure your card has a chip. "If you are a customer of a financial institution and you don't have a chip card, it would be a good idea to reach out to them," Wilcox said. "The chip cards, they're gonna do more for you as far as protection. The way that they work is really the most secure card they have." While police are investigating those responsible for the scam, they said banks are helping victims get their money back. "What we're seeing with a majority of these reports, the banking institutions are working very well with these victims," Grubbs said. "Once it's clearly established this is fraud, they're putting the money back into these peoples' accounts. We will be working on behalf of these banking institutions to make an arrest."   Filed in: News Suggest a correction × Suggest A Correction Your name Your email Report a typo or grammatical error Cancel Share this: Facebook Twitter Google Pinterest LinkedIn Email Leave a Reply Cancel reply Enter your comment here... - - - - Jobs Homes Autos Classifieds - - - - - Trib Total Media Contact Us Feedback Blogs Email Newsletters eTrib Digital Replica Our Publications eFeatures Buy Trib Photos Where to Buy the Paper World Ohio State attacker faulted 'moderate' Muslims The Associated Press | Thursday, June 1, 2017, 11:27 a.m. In this Monday, Nov. 28, 2016 file photo, investigators collect evidence as police respond to an attack at Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio. Abdul Razak Ali Artan, 18, was shot and killed by an Ohio State officer moments after driving into a crowd and then attacking people with a knife. Email Newsletters Sign up for one of our email newsletters. Updated 13 hours ago COLUMBUS, Ohio — The man responsible for a car-and-knife attack at Ohio State University last year left behind a torn-up note in which he urged his family to stop being “moderate” Muslims and said he was upset by fellow Muslims being oppressed in Myanmar, The Associated Press has learned. Abdul Razak Ali Artan also told his parents in the note, reassembled by investigators, that he “will intercede for you in the day of Judgment,” according to the investigative case file of the attack obtained through an open records request. “My family stop being moderate muslims,” says the handwritten note transcribed by investigators and found by Artan's bed in his family's apartment. Artan also wrote: “In the end, I would like to say that I pledge my allegiance to ‘dawla,'” an Arabic word that means state or country and a likely reference to the Islamic State group. “May Allah bless them.” He concludes by saying he's leaving his property to his beloved “but yet ‘moderate mother.'” Artan's family was baffled by that note, which caused them a great deal of anguish, said Bob Fitrakis, a Columbus attorney representing the family. To this day, the family has no idea why Artan took those actions, he said Thursday. “The family is mystified by what happened. They're absolutely clueless,” Fitrakis said. The 18-year-old Artan was shot and killed by an Ohio State officer moments after driving into a crowd on Nov. 28 and then attacking people with a knife, leaving thirteen injured. In a series of Facebook rants previously reported, Artan nursed grievances against the U.S. “If you want us Muslims to stop carrying lone wolf attacks, then make peace” with the Islamic State group, he warned in those posts in which he also railed against U.S. intervention in Muslim lands. Artan posted those comments at 9:49 a.m. on Nov. 28, three minutes before the attack began, according to an unclassified FBI report showing the time line of the attack that was released through the open records request. One of his brothers saw those comments and tried too late to contact him, thinking maybe it was a joke or his account had been hacked, Fitrakis said. The records provided new details about Artan, including a visit he made to Washington, D.C. a few days before the attack where he also made unidentified purchases at a Walmart. The family didn't realize he'd traveled there, has no idea why he went, and urges anyone with information about that trip to contact authorities, Fitrakis said. The day before the attack, Artan left his job at a nearby Home Depot, saying he was tired, a co-worker told investigators. This was unusual, “as he never left early from work,” the co-worker said. Artan had told the co-worker several times that fall he was disgruntled with school and wanted to drop out, according to the records. The morning of the attack, Artan bought a set of knives, a tomato and a cucumber at 7:20 a.m. at a Walmart on the west side of Columbus, with his movements captured by video and photos and released in response to the AP's records' request. The “suspect was pleasant and very polite during the checkout process,” the Walmart cashier told investigators. At 7:50 a.m., Artan dropped his sister at a high school near their home on the city's west side. He paid a brother $40 he owed him around 9:30 a.m., when the brother last saw him, according to FBI records. After arriving on campus, Artan drove his brother's Honda Civic over a curb and into a crowd of people and crashed it into a planter. Artan then got out and started slashing at people with an eight-inch knife, records show. In a coincidence, a nearby building had been evacuated because of a reported gas leak. “I'm going to . . . kill you,” Artan told one female student, using an expletive, the records show. Somali-born Artan came to the U.S. in 2014 as the child of a refugee. He had been living in Pakistan from 2007 to 2014. Authorities believe Artan's attack was partly inspired by an American-born cleric killed in a U.S. drone strike in Yemen. ___ Andrew Welsh-Huggins can be reached on Twitter at https://twitter.com/awhcolumbus. His work can be found at http://bigstory.ap.org/content/andrew-welsh-huggins More Nation/World Trump turns to Supreme Court to move forward on travel ban 36 die from smoke in Philippine casino after gunman set fire Trump's remarks on pulling out of climate accord Homeland Security chief Kelly signals shift on immigration program Nightclub massacre bodycam video documents officer response TribLIVE commenting policy You are solely responsible for your comments and by using TribLive.com you agree to our Terms of Service. We moderate comments. Our goal is to provide substantive commentary for a general readership. By screening submissions, we provide a space where readers can share intelligent and informed commentary that enhances the quality of our news and information. While most comments will be posted if they are on-topic and not abusive, moderating decisions are subjective. We will make them as carefully and consistently as we can. Because of the volume of reader comments, we cannot review individual moderation decisions with readers. We value thoughtful comments representing a range of views that make their point quickly and politely. We make an effort to protect discussions from repeated comments either by the same reader or different readers We follow the same standards for taste as the daily newspaper. A few things we won't tolerate: personal attacks, obscenity, vulgarity, profanity (including expletives and letters followed by dashes), commercial promotion, impersonations, incoherence, proselytizing and SHOUTING. Don't include URLs to Web sites. We do not edit comments. They are either approved or deleted. We reserve the right to edit a comment that is quoted or excerpted in an article. In this case, we may fix spelling and punctuation. We welcome strong opinions and criticism of our work, but we don't want comments to become bogged down with discussions of our policies and we will moderate accordingly. We appreciate it when readers and people quoted in articles or blog posts point out errors of fact or emphasis and will investigate all assertions. But these suggestions should be sent via e-mail. To avoid distracting other readers, we won't publish comments that suggest a correction. Instead, corrections will be made in a blog post or in an article. business editor at large Market Watch: How to invest in future tech 3:56 PM Thursday Jun 1, 2017 SHARE: Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Not saved Email Print Business Services Investment Companies Market Watch Mobile Business Personal Investment Sponsor message.   Video will play in Play now Don't auto play Never auto play New technology trends present great opportunities for investors but getting the timing right isn't easy, says Pie Funds chief executive Mike Taylor. Three big trends were currently shaking up the business landscape, Taylor said. Electric cars, renewable energy and online retailing were all approaching the tipping point where they could start to make major social changes. "If we look at something like retail and the move to online, the tech bubble occurred 17 years ago," Taylor said. "Internet stocks went to the moon between 1995 and 2001, then they collapsed and most of them went out of business. It's actually been 15 years after the move to online has really gathered momentum." So if you look at the stock price of a traditional retailer like Walmart and an online retailer like Amazon, it is only in the past few years that they have really started to diverge. Getting the timing right for investing in big tech trends required getting in at the right time in the cycle, Taylor said. The two options were to get in very early when technology was first developed or to go in the second phase after the initial wave of hype had died down and the technology was actually being adopted. "What you don't want to do is buy into a bubble. So when the technology is new and emerging and not widely adopted you've got to be careful you're not buying an over hyped asset class." Fo most investors it made more sense to get involved when the technology was on the verge of going mainstream. Another recent example was solar energy which was extremely hot as an investment just prior to the GFC. Again they collapsed but now as technological advances lowered the cost of solar for consumers it was starting to reach critical mass. Investing in individual stocks could still be risky for small investors but there were options like clean energy funds that offered exposure to the wider renewable energy sector and even ETF's that covered specific sectors like online retail. - NZ Herald Read more by Liam Dann Email Liam Dann Email Print Get the news delivered straight to your inbox Receive the day’s news, sport and entertainment in our daily email newsletter SIGN UP NOW Loading Currency Compare and convert world currencies.
